Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: reserved band at rim, glazed black below; elaborate rosette with added red centres and added white outline; exterior: at rim, broken maeander band between pairs of dilute lines; below, black-figure decoration consisting females wearing an elaborate polos, to left; back of head of woman on left (with red on hair and polos) and part of face of woman on right.
Curator's comments: The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1924,1201.206, 1924,1201.204 and 1924,1201.342. The sherd belongs to the group of Chian black figure vases bearing Laconising features. According to Williams, the chalice is by the same painter as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.133.2 and AN1896-1908-G.133.6 whom he has identified as the Sirens Painter. The Sirens Painter pieces most closely resemble those by the Laconian painter known as the Boreads Painter, primarily because of the single pomegranate band on the tondo of the Oxford kylix.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 154, 157-60, p. 323, no. 1463, pl. 193)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 130, fig. 16; p. 132 note 65)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0876) (phase 2)
